metadata.title: The Number Factory: Punched-Card Machines at the Dutch Central Bureau of Statistics
metadata.journal_or_publisher: IEEE Annals of the History of Computing

relevance.topic: Application of punched-card machinery for data processing at the Dutch Central Bureau of Statistics
relevance.relevance: The study is relevant as it explores the historical labor displacement and organizational changes due to the introduction of punched-card machines, a precursor to digital computing.

design.sample_characteristics: Focus on the Dutch Central Bureau of Statistics and its employees.

dependent_variables.displaced: Manual data processing workers were displaced by punched-card machines.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: Not explicitly mentioned, but there was a shift in labor roles.

key_themes: Mechanization and automation of data processing
Technological advancement and its impact on labor
text_fragments: The DCBS subjected the tallying and calculating work to increasing degrees of mechanization and automation.
The punched-card method was especially suited to complex statistics.
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes the transition from manual to mechanized data processing at the DCBS, highlighting the organizational and labor changes that accompanied the adoption of punched-card machines.

historical_context.economic_conditions: The study covers periods of economic growth, the 1930s economic crisis, and post-war recovery.
historical_context.institutional_context: The DCBS was an independent office focusing on social statistics, influenced by government and societal demands for data.

outcomes.main_findings: The increasing mechanization and automation at the DCBS were driven by the growing complexity and volume of statistical work, rather than just technological advancements.
outcomes.conclusions: The study concludes that the demand for more complex and accurate statistics was the primary driver for the adoption of punched-card machines and later digital computers at the DCBS.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The study suggests that the mechanization and automation of data processing had lasting impacts on labor organization and the role of women in the workforce.

quality_assessment.methodological_limitations: The study is based on historical records and may not capture all perspectives, particularly those of the workers affected.
quality_assessment.coherence: The study provides a coherent narrative linking technological changes to labor displacement and organizational changes.
quality_assessment.adequacy_of_data: The study uses a rich set of historical data from archives and reports, providing a detailed account of the period.
quality_assessment.relevance: The study is highly relevant to understanding the historical impact of technological change on labor displacement.
